sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Dasabuvir has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU).
  • Efficacy and safety not established in patients with hepatitis C and hepatitis B coinfection.
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection: HCV genotype 1a without cirrhosis: 250 mg orally twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin (and HIV antiviral agents); continue HCV treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection: HCV genotype 1a with compensated cirrhosis: 250 mg orally twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin (and HIV antiviral agents); continue HCV treatment for 24 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection: HCV genotype 1b without cirrhosis: 250 mg orally twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir (and HIV antiviral agents); continue HCV treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection: HCV genotype 1b with compensated cirrhosis: 250 mg orally twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin (and HIV antiviral agents); continue HCV treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - Transplantation of liver: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin; consider lower ribavirin dose at initiation (ribavirin study dose, 600 to 800 mg/day); continue treatment for 24 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - Transplantation of liver: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a with compensated cirrhosis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin; continue treatment for 24 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a with compensated cirrhosis: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a without cirrhosis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a without cirrhosis: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b with compensated cirrhosis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir plus ribavirin; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b with compensated cirrhosis: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b without cirrhosis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily in the morning and evening with food in combination with ombitasvir/paritaprevir/ritonavir; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b without cirrhosis: Missed dose: If dose cannot be taken within 6 hours, skip that dose and take the next dose at the usual time

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Efficacy and safety not established in patients younger than 18 years.

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment: No dosage adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A): No dosage adjustment required
  • Hepatic impairment, moderate (Child-Pugh class B): No dosage adjustment expected based on pharmacokinetic studies; efficacy and safety not established
  • Hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh class C): Do not use
  • Elderly: No dosage adjustment required

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - HIV infection
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a or 1b - Transplantation of liver
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a with compensated cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1a without cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b with compensated cirrhosis
  • Hepatitis C, chronic, Genotype 1b without cirrhosis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Concomitant use of ethinyl estradiol-containing products (ie, oral contraceptives or contraceptive vaginal rings); increased risk of ALT elevations
  • Concomitant use of strong CYP2C8 inhibitors (ie, gemfibrozil)
  • Concomitant use of strong or moderate enzyme inducers (ie, carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, efavirenz, nevirapine, etravirine, enzalutamide, mitotane, rifampicin, or St. John's wort)
  • Hypersensitivity to dasabuvir or any excipients of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Do not use in patients with galactose intolerance, Lapp lactase deficiency, or glucose-galactose malabsorption
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Use not recommended in patients with severe hepatic impairment; safety not established in moderate impairment
  • -- ALT elevations have been reported
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Fetal harm may occur if ribavirin is administered to a pregnant woman; effective contraception is required during treatment and for at least 6 months following discontinuation
  • Other:
  • -- Use not recommended in coinfected HIV patients without suppressive antiretroviral therapy or in those coinfected with hepatitis B
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Coadministration with antivirals other than ombitasvir, paritaprevir, ribavirin, and ritonavir is not recommended

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (1% to 10% or more)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (10% or more)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (1% to less than 10%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (10% or more), Insomnia (10% or more)
  • Other:Fatigue (10% or more)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Decreased hemoglobin, Grade 3 or 4 (grade 3, 0.1% to 0.8%; grade 4, 0.3%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised, Grade 3 or 4 (0.2% to 1.1%), Increased bilirubin level, Grade 3 or 4 (0.1% to 9.7%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Dasabuvir is an HCV non-nucleoside NS5B palm polymerase inhibitor. Dasabuvir inhibits replication of the HCV viral genome.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 4 to 5 hours
  • Effects of food: AUC increased up to 30%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Metabolites, M1: active
  • Substrate of CYP2C8 and CYP3A
  • Inhibitor of BCRP and UGT1A1, UGT1A4, UGT1A6, and intestinal UGT2B7

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • Swallow tablets whole; do not chew, break, or dissolve tablets.
  • Take with food.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• determine hepatitis C virus genotype prior to initiation of therapy
  • reduction in HCV-RNA viral load and improvement in signs/symptoms of chronic hepatitis C genotype 1 infection may indicate efficacy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to report symptoms of liver disease.
  • Encourage patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized due to potential for fatigue.
  • Side effects may include anemia, insomnia, nausea, pruritus, or asthenia.
  • Encourage patient to take drug with food.
  • Tell patient to take a missed dose as soon as possible, but if next dose is in less than 6 hours, skip the missed dose.
